title: Seahawks-49ers preview
text:
A preview of tonight's matchup between two 2-4 NFC West teams. Post to Facebook Seahawks-49ers preview A preview of tonight's matchup between two 2-4 NFC West teams. Check out this story on wtsp.com: http://on.wtsp.com/1LQ5V3z Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Seahawks-49ers preview Chris Traspasso, CBS SPORTS 7:28 p.m. EDT October 22, 2015 Thursdayâ€™s game will be the first since 2009 in which the 49ers and Seahawks enter the game with losing records. Both are 2-4. (Photo: Associated Press) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
( CBS SPORTS ) -- The San Francisco 49ers sitting at 2-4 through six games is not necessarily surprising, but not many prognosticators envisioned a 2-4 start for Russell Wilson and the Seattle Seahawks . 
Over the past five years, this rivalry has carried significant weight, and this Thursday Night Football showdown is no different -- even with both teams under .500. 
Here are the five advanced stats you need to know for this key NFC West battle. NFL Today: TNF preview 
1. Calm under pressure 
Most quarterbacks are drastically worse under pressure than when they're comfortably surveying the field from a clean pocket. 
That's logical. 
Beyond that, continual pressure typically "ruins" signal-callers -- as repeated pressure asks for repeated improvisational play and usually accuracy outside the pocket while on the run. 
Of all quarterbacks in the NFL, Russell Wilson is the most acclimated to pressure -- some of the pressure he faces is on him -- and he has been remarkably good with a defender bearing down on him, especially this season. 
Check out these insane numbers. 
RUSSELL WILSON UNDER PRESSURE 
YEAR UNDER PRESSURE % (RANK) ACCURACY % UNDER PRESSURE (RANK) 
2015 46.8 (1) 77.8 (3) 
2014 46.0 (1) 68.6 (6) 
2013 43.8 (1) 61.9 (11) 
2012 39.2 (2) 66.0 (5) 
Seattle's offensive line hasn't necessarily been a team strength for the past two or three years, and Wilson undoubtedly tends to channel his amazing backyard football skills quicker than others, but his under pressure numbers are outrageous. 
Note that since 2013, he has gotten more accurate in these situations, and while a six-game sample size may be helping his 2015 Accuracy Percentage here, nearly a 10-percentage point jump from a season ago is impressive. 
Russell Wilson is not only elusive, he's very effective under pressure. (Photo: USA TODAY SPORTS IMAGES) 
For perspective on Wilson's 77.8 percentage: Andrew Luck is currently last in the NFL with an Under Pressure Accuracy Percentage of 47.1. 
Aaron Rodgers is at 67.5 percent and Tom Brady is at 68.3. 
2. Carlos Hyde , the NFL's most underrated RB? 
When it comes down to it, the fundamental skill that separates running backs is the ability to forced missed tackles -- and maybe avoid them altogether. 
While it's extremely hard to decipher how a runner completely "avoids" a would-be tackle by making a cut into open space, Pro Football Focus does track when a tackler is there, and a running back forces that tackler to miss. 
This may be somewhat surprising to some, but 49ers running back Carlos Hyde leads the NFL in missed tackles forced and is second in missed tackles divided by total touches among the top 10 runners in total missed tackles forced and total touches. 
LEADERS IN MISSED TACKLES FORCED 
PLAYER TOTAL TOUCHES MISSED TACKLES FORCED MISSED TACKLE % 
Melvin Gordon 91 26 28.5 
Carlos Hyde 115 31 26.9 
Le'Veon Bell 104 21 20.1 
Source: Pro Football Focus 
And it's not like Hyde is running through a parted Red Sea on every snap. In fact, quite the opposite. According to Pro Football Focus, the 49ers have a minus-30.9 cumulative run-blocking score, the second-worst in football. Because of that, it's easy to assume San Francisco's offensive line will have issues with Seattle's ferocious defensive front. 
However, even if he's not given massive holes to run through, Hyde should be able showcase his supreme elusiveness. 
By the way, Marshawn Lynch only has 65 total touches this season -- therefore he didn't qualify for the above chart -- and has forced 18 missed tackles, which puts his missed tackles percentage at 27.6. Safe to say, he's the same old Marshawn Lynch. 
3. Super pass-rushers 
Michael Bennett , Cliff Avril and Aaron Lynch are three of the most effective pass rushers in the NFC. 
Bennett is probably the most well-known of the bunch, and he has been a consistent disruptor for years. So has Avril. 
But check out the jump Lynch has made in his second professional season. 
PRESSURING THE QUARTERBACK 
PLAYER 2014 QB PRESSURES 2015 QB PRESSURES PACE 
Michael Bennett 72 72 
Aaron Lynch 41 74.6 
Source: Pro Football Focus 
Sure, Lynch is seeing the field more than he did as a rookie, but he's nearly doubling his production as the primary stand-in for Aldon Smith , and he doesn't have Justin Smith eating double teams on the interior. 
While the amount of top-level talent the 49ers lost this past offseason was astonishing and definitely well-documented, Lynch is emerging as the leader of the new wave of talent in San Francisco. 
He'll be a handful for the Seahawks' offensive tackles in this one. 
Aaron Lynch is emerging as a leader for the 49ers' defense. (Photo: USA TODAY SPORTS IMAGES) 
4. Hey, Colin ... throw it to Torrey 
Torrey Smith was brought to the 49ers to stretch the field and give Colin Kaepernick a speedster that would (hopefully) ameliorate the quarterback's effectiveness down the field. 
Thus far, Smith has done just that, but he probably needs to see the ball more. Take a look at his production and usage numbers this season compared to the rest of his career. 
TORREY SMITH'S PRODUCTION 
2015 YARDS PER CATCH (RANK) CAREER YARDS PER CATCH CAREER TARGETS PER SEASON 2015 TARGET PACE 
Smith 23.1 (1) 16.8 109 67 
Source: Pro Football Focus 
Also, Smith's highest final-season catch percentage is 53, which he had in 2014 with the Ravens. His current catch percentage is 56. 
So, basically, while the small sample size must be kept in mind, what Smith has accomplished through six games in San Francisco is enough to recommend that he should be a more frequent target in the 49ers passing offense. 
5. Hey, Carlos ... run left 
As previously mentioned, Hyde is an unheralded, exceptional talent. A lot of his yardage comes when he eludes a tackler or breaks free from a defender. 
Despite issues on the right side of the 49ers' line, the tandem of left tackle Joe Staley and left guard Alex Boone is tremendous, and often paves massive holes for the second-year runner. 
Check how productive Hyde has been while running behind Staley or Boone in 2015. 
CARLOS HYDE'S PRODUCTION 
CARLOS HYDE CARRIES YARDS YARDS PER CARRY TDS 
Behind Staley and/or Boone 25 179 7.16 2 
Source: Pro Football Focus 
Talk about efficiency. 
If anything, it can be argued that Hyde should carry the football left more often, as only 25 percent of his 104 carries on the season have gone directly behind Staley or Boone. 
Prediction: Seahawks 20, 49ers 17 
This contest will be closer than expected. The 49ers have big-play potential with Smith, Anquan Boldin is still a reliable chain mover and San Francisco's defensive front seven is underrated. 
It wouldn't surprise me if Jim Tomsula's club holds a lead in the second half, but the Seahawks will mount a mini comeback and win a close one, with much thanks to Marshawn Lynch's punishing running style, Russell Wilson's improvisational skills and a few stagnant possessions by the 49ers offense late in the game.
